security_audit.summary: This skill is a legitimate browser automation tool. It starts the official Playwright MCP server, uses a Python HTTP client to communicate with it, and provides standard browser automation capabilities. No credential theft, data exfiltration, or malicious patterns detected.

low_findings.title: PID file in /tmp directory
low_findings.description:
The start-server.sh script writes a PID file to /tmp/playwright-mcp-${PORT}.pid. While this is standard practice, /tmp is world-writable and an attacker with local access could potentially manipulate it. The PID file is used to track the running server process.

Code location: scripts/start-server.sh:16
```bash
echo $! > "$PID_FILE"
```

low_findings.title: Shell=True in subprocess for stdio transport
low_findings.description:
The mcp-client.py uses shell=True in subprocess.Popen for stdio transport (line 204-211). This can introduce command injection risks if user input is passed unsafely to the command. However, in this context, the command is constructed from fixed strings and the --stdio argument is intended for local MCP servers.

Code location: scripts/mcp-client.py:204-211
```python
self._process = subprocess.Popen(
    self.command,
    shell=True,
    ...
)
```

content.value_statement: Manual browser tasks waste time. This skill provides programmatic browser automation through Playwright MCP, enabling navigation, form filling, data extraction, and testing without manual intervention.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and navigate back through browser history
Click, type, hover, and drag elements on web pages
Fill forms with multiple fields including textboxes, checkboxes, and dropdowns
Take screenshots of pages or specific elements
Extract data using JavaScript evaluation or page snapshots
Wait for elements or conditions before proceeding with automation
limitations: Requires Playwright browser to be installed on the system
Only controls one browser instance per MCP server session
Cannot bypass authentication or access password-protected areas without credentials

use_cases.title: Automated UI testing
use_cases.description: Test web application functionality by automating user flows, form submissions, and assertions

use_cases.title: Web scraping workflows
use_cases.description: Extract structured data from websites by navigating pages and capturing content programmatically

use_cases.title: Form validation testing
use_cases.description: Test form behavior by filling inputs, checking validation messages, and verifying submission outcomes

prompt_templates.title: Navigate and explore
prompt_templates.scenario: Visit a website and understand its structure
prompt_templates.prompt: Go to {URL} and take a snapshot to see what elements are available on the page.

prompt_templates.title: Fill a form
prompt_templates.scenario: Complete an online form with specific data
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to {URL}, fill in the form fields with: {field_data}, then submit it and wait for confirmation.

prompt_templates.title: Extract data
prompt_templates.scenario: Scrape structured information from a webpage
prompt_templates.prompt: Go to {URL}, get a page snapshot, and extract all {data_type} information into a structured format.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-step workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform this workflow: 1) Navigate to {start_url}, 2) Click the {element}, 3) Fill {field} with {value}, 4) Submit, 5) Take a screenshot of the result.

output_examples.input: Go to example.com and show me the main content
output: Main content area found with heading 'Example Domain' and paragraph text
Screenshot saved showing the page layout

best_practices: Start the MCP server before beginning browser tasks to maintain browser context across operations
Take a page snapshot before interacting with elements to get accurate element references
Use browser_wait_for to ensure pages have fully loaded before attempting interactions
anti_patterns: Running browser automation without first checking if the server is running
Attempting to click elements without first obtaining current page snapshot references
Not closing the browser when tasks complete, leaving zombie processes running

faq.question: Which browsers does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill supports Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit browsers through Playwright. Chromium is used by default.

faq.question: What are the resource limits for browser automation?
faq.answer: Browser automation uses system memory for the browser process. Large page loads or many open tabs may increase memory usage.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with other MCP servers?
faq.answer: The mcp-client.py script can connect to any MCP server that supports HTTP transport. Use the --url flag to specify the server endpoint.

faq.question: Is my browsing data stored or shared?
faq.answer: All browser activity occurs locally on your machine. No browsing data is transmitted to external servers by this skill.

faq.question: Why is my element click failing?
faq.answer: The page may have changed since the last snapshot. Run browser_snapshot again to get updated element references before interacting.

faq.question: How does this compare to other browser tools?
faq.answer: This skill uses the official Playwright MCP server, providing full browser automation. Other tools may offer simpler navigation only.
